commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: I46f916bfe0078a43ec6537e4e3e71be44acd4891
(cherry picked from commit c357ce1f13496ce51666e5ae2981f7ea0b86c27c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron refs/changes/64/339664/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: minversion = 2.0install_command = pip install -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt} {opts} {packages} deps = -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = /usr/bin/find . -type f -name "*.pyc" -delete http_proxy HTTP_PROXY https_proxy HTTPS_PROXY no_proxy NO_PROXY wget bash -c "rm -rf doc/build"[testenv:releasenotes] # NOTE(sdague): this target does not use constraints because # upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} commands = sphinx-build -a -E -W -d releasenotes/build/doctrees -b html releasenotes/source releasenotes/build/html # NOTE(jaegerandi): this target does not use constraints because # upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} commands = {posargs}[testenv:ansible] deps = {[testenv]deps} ansible==1.9.4 ansible-lint>=2.7.0,<3.0.0 setenv = {[testenv]setenv} ANSIBLE_HOST_KEY_CHECKING = False ANSIBLE_SSH_CONTROL_PATH = /tmp/%%h-%%r # TODO (odyssey4me) These are only here as they are non-standard folder # names for Ansible 1.9.x. We are using the standard folder names for # Ansible v2.x. We can remove this when we move to Ansible 2.x. ANSIBLE_ACTION_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/action ANSIBLE_CALLBACK_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback ANSIBLE_FILTER_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/filter ANSIBLE_LOOKUP_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/lookup # This is required as the default is the current path or a path specified # in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_LIBRARY = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/library # This is required as the default is '/etc/ansible/roles' or a path # specified in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_ROLES_PATH = {homedir}/.ansible/roles:{toxinidir}/.. rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/plugins # This plugin makes the ansible-playbook output easier to read wget -O {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback/human_log.py \ https://gist.githubusercontent.com/cliffano/9868180/raw/f360f306b3c6d689734a6aa8773a00edf16a0054/human_log.py rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/roles [testenv:ansible-syntax] deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv} commands = {[testenv:ansible]commands}deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} ansible-lint {toxinidir}# NOTE(odyssey4me): this target does not use constraints because # it doesn't work in OpenStack-CI yet. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv} {[testenv:ansible]commands} -e "install_test_packages=True" \ {toxinidir}/tests/test.yml -vvvvdeps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv}
deleted_lines: minversion = 1.6install_command = pip install -U {opts} {packages} deps = -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = /usr/bin/find . -type f -name "*.pyc" -delete echo curl ANSIBLE_HOST_KEY_CHECKING = False ANSIBLE_SSH_CONTROL_PATH = /tmp/%%h-%%r # TODO (odyssey4me) These are only here as they are non-standard folder # names for Ansible 1.9.x. We are using the standard folder names for # Ansible v2.x. We can remove this when we move to Ansible 2.x. ANSIBLE_ACTION_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/action ANSIBLE_CALLBACK_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback ANSIBLE_FILTER_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/filter ANSIBLE_LOOKUP_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/lookup # This is required as the default is the current path or a path specified # in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_LIBRARY = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/library # This is required as the default is '/etc/ansible/roles' or a path # specified in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_ROLES_PATH = {homedir}/.ansible/roles:{toxinidir}/..deps = -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = {posargs}# The max-line-length is being set at a greater width in order to accommodate # jinja templating in python files, especially in the shebang. max-line-length = 120[testenv:ansible-syntax] rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible --ignore-errors \ ansible-lint {toxinidir}/tests/test.yml rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins \ {homedir}/.ansible/plugins ansible-galaxy install \ --role-file={toxinidir}/tests/ansible-role-requirements.yml \ --ignore-errors \ --force -vv \ {toxinidir}/tests/test.yml [testenv:releasenotes] commands = sphinx-build -a -E -d releasenotes/build/doctrees -b html releasenotes/source releasenotes/build/html

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: I51af7598075995efc3d755a57daf0f82f972a4a4
(cherry picked from commit 2201cf871f0ba86f81d05a06d5265e2dcc5d4fb0)

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: Ie08d1c8c82220e496bfa6d8b6743b5b3318c72ed
(cherry picked from commit eb495e4d80343fe9a2dca337d6ea8f8013d5f396)

Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} commands = sphinx-build -a -E -W -d releasenotes/build/doctrees -b html releasenotes/source releasenotes/build/html # NOTE(jaegerandi): this target does not use constraints because # upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} commands = {posargs}[testenv:ansible] deps = {[testenv]deps} ansible==1.9.4 ansible-lint>=2.7.0,<3.0.0 setenv = {[testenv]setenv} ANSIBLE_HOST_KEY_CHECKING = False ANSIBLE_SSH_CONTROL_PATH = /tmp/%%h-%%r # TODO (odyssey4me) These are only here as they are non-standard folder # names for Ansible 1.9.x. We are using the standard folder names for # Ansible v2.x. We can remove this when we move to Ansible 2.x. ANSIBLE_ACTION_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/action ANSIBLE_CALLBACK_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback ANSIBLE_FILTER_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/filter ANSIBLE_LOOKUP_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/lookup # This is required as the default is the current path or a path specified # in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_LIBRARY = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/library # This is required as the default is '/etc/ansible/roles' or a path # specified in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_ROLES_PATH = {homedir}/.ansible/roles:{toxinidir}/.. rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/plugins # This plugin makes the ansible-playbook output easier to read wget -O {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback/human_log.py \ https://gist.githubusercontent.com/cliffano/9868180/raw/f360f306b3c6d689734a6aa8773a00edf16a0054/human_log.py rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/roles [testenv:ansible-syntax] deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv} commands = {[testenv:ansible]commands}deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} ansible-lint {toxinidir}# NOTE(odyssey4me): this target does not use constraints because # it doesn't work in OpenStack-CI yet. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv} {[testenv:ansible]commands} -e "install_test_packages=True" \ {toxinidir}/tests/test.yml -vvvvdeps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv}

commit_message:
LDAP preprocessing

Change-Id: I9a94e61dc7b48334e252512b43d8f27c18a4ac81
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/00/339600/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Example Spec - The title of your blueprint ========================================== `bp example <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/example>`_ Keystone can use LDAP as an identity backend. LDAP attributes probably are not uuid4, and we need our entities have uuid4 ids. To perform ldap_attribute <-> keystone_id mapping, there is id_mapping_api. However, it is very slow when there are many identities. Problem Description =================== id_mapping_api is a mapping layer between LDAP entities and keystone entities. When an operation on an entity needs to be performed, id_mapping_api changes the id from public (uuid4) to local (LDAP-specific) or vise versa. It does that by looking up public and local id for each entity. For N users in LDAP it makes N SELECT queries to the database. Even worse, if M entities don't yet have a public id, id_mapping_api performs M INSERT queries. All of this happens when a user makes an API call to keystone. When N and M are big, the call will result in timeout. The problem with N SELECT queries can be worked around by selecting all rows from the mapping table and performing the lookup for public or local id in memory. However, the problem with M INSERT queries cannot be worked around so easily. One might want to use bulk insert. However, race condition might happen in this case: + Process 1 | Process 2 +-------------+ Select entities #1, #2, #3 | Select entity #2 from the table; 0 returned | from the table; 0 returned since they don't exist yet | since it does not exist yet +-------------+ | Generate public id for #2 | Insert public_id for #2 | +-------------+ Generate public_id for | #1, #2, #3. Bulk insert | for all items. | | v At this point process 1 will fail because there is already an entry about entity #2. It cannot be ignored, because the id, assigned in process 2, was already returned to the user. Proposed Change =============== Implement new command for `keystone-manage`: `prepare_ldap`. It will: 1. Fetch all users from LDAP 2. For all users create a mapping The command will be executed by operators, when they know that LDAP has many entries. Running the command **is not required** for integrating LDAP. It will provide a better user and operator experience for cases when there are many entities in LDAP. Alternatives ------------ Only implement a workaround for N SELECT queries. Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ The workaround with N queries it will decrease the number of SQL queries to constant number and will require O(N) additional memory. `keystone-manage prepare-ldap` command will be ran by operators. It will not be exposed to the users. It will speed-up the first call or the call after many new LDAP users were added. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers will have an ability to run the command right after configuring LDAP. It is not a requirement to run it. No existing deployment scripts will be affected. Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: bbobrov (breton) Dependencies ============ No dependencies Documentation Impact ==================== Document the new command. References ========== * https://review.openstack.org/339294 * https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/identity/core.py#L569

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: Iae6b20a4f6c4d8156a55977dfa81b3fa5cd53034
(cherry picked from commit 501f4fcddd7b4d1c1a4580bcd9736b9a6ee54984)

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: If42e739002e36669044a9396e233dbd382add4c8
(cherry picked from commit 65293e8002b794d75bc7fbe82c192711da1eb08d)

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

commit_message:
Add internal_info field to ports and portgroups

In case of ports, it is also added to the API, as a readonly field.
It will be used for any port-specific internal information ironic
needs to store inside the port object. In this change we start using
it to store UUIDs of the cleaning ports that ironic creates, instead
of fiddling with port.extra['vif_port_id'], as extra is intended for
operator use only.

Partial-bug: #1526403

Change-Id: Ib62c3e32305619d0c55f8ec7e45b067f0f0b32d4

commit_message:
Opt in test instance apt repo mirror configs

Rather than enabling ceph and cloud archive repos by default when when
configuring test instances to use our apt repo mirrors write out
configures for them in another directory which can be optionally
enabled.

This prevents growing dependencies on these repositories except for
where explicitly desired.

To use a mirror either symlink to the sources.list.available.d/ files or
copy them into sources.list.d/ and rerun apt-get update.

Change-Id: I410f45064080e1bb93684899028e9af34bd555a1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/28/339628/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Opt in repos sudo mkdir -p /etc/apt/sources.list.available.d sudo dd of=/etc/apt/sources.list.available.d/ceph-deb-hammer.list <<EOF deb $NODEPOOL_CEPH_MIRROR $LSBDISTCODENAME main EOF # Keep this for backward compat until devstack ceph plugin is updated

commit_message:
Gemfile: pin json to <=1.8.3

json 2.x requires ruby 2.x and lint jobs run on trusty that provides
ruby1.0.

Until we sort things out in infra, let's pin json.

Change-Id: Ie04ee90bc2cab149a2f86f1cf54b8434432e9a14
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/48/339648/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gem 'json', '<=1.8.3', :require => 'false'

subject: Ensure that gate test does not remove ~/.ansible/tmp
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-08 15:43:54.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-memcached_server/commit/99e5aee3017c95648debdbd03953e4ee295844f4', 'message': 'Ensure that gate test does not remove ~/.ansible/tmp

As zuul uses Ansible the ~/.ansible directory is populated with
artifacts which zuul uses to facilitate the job execution.

This patch ensures that the execution of tests does not remove

parts which we populate.

'}]
commit_message:
Ensure that gate test does not remove ~/.ansible/tmp

As zuul uses Ansible the ~/.ansible directory is populated with
artifacts which zuul uses to facilitate the job execution.

This patch ensures that the execution of tests does not remove
the whole ~/.ansible directory, but instead only removes the
parts which we populate.

Change-Id: I299f19cd999869dd3f41d24fbdad044816998866
(cherry picked from commit 2858aa0656cf47e27c62738472568702adb77ebe)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-memcached_server refs/changes/30/339630/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible

commit_message:
HAProxy uses milliseconds for its timeout values.

Match the documentation to the reality of the implementation.

Change-Id: I4919ca426353adeb4874712d821bfd0428792aaa

commit_message:
Huawei: Use versionedObject

Since the core code has been changed to use
versionedObject, Huawei drivers now changes to
use versionedObject too.

Implements: blueprint huawei-use-versionedobject
Change-Id: I4d0e7ac804a9d42754e7f7ce70cdd8af132e173a

commit_message:
Run flake8 against scripts in bin

Just having a `flake8 --filename=swift* bin` command is insufficient.

Change-Id: Ia2a5c364e52d9972d31e6b5e22366503894b720d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/91/339191/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: filename = *.py,bin/*

commit_message:
Alternative console authorization object

This is trying out an idea.

Change-Id: I7b782daa3517ce5dc4a395fe5e5212ec8a52eeba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/35/335535/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid from oslo_db.exception import DBDuplicateEntry from oslo_utils import timeutils from nova import db from nova import exception from nova.objects import base from nova.objects import fields from nova import utils @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register class ConsoleConnection(base.NovaTimestampObject, base.NovaObject): # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'id': fields.IntegerField(), 'console_type': fields.StringField(nullable=False), 'host': fields.StringField(nullable=False), 'port': fields.IntegerField(nullable=False), 'internal_access_path': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'instance_uuid': fields.UUIDField(nullable=False), 'access_url_base': fields.StringField(nullable=False), 'token_hash': fields.StringField(nullable=False), 'expires': fields.IntegerField(nullable=False) } @staticmethod def _from_db_object(context, obj, db_obj): for field in obj.fields: setattr(obj, field, db_obj[field]) obj._context = context obj.obj_reset_changes() return obj @base.remotable_classmethod def get(cls, context, token_hash, instance_uuid): db_obj = db.console_auth_token_get_valid( context, token_hash, instance_uuid) return cls._from_db_object(context, ConsoleConnection(), db_obj) @base.remotable_classmethod def create(self): updates = self.obj_get_changes() try: db_obj = db.console_auth_token_create(self._context, updates) return self._from_db_object(self._context, self, db_obj) except DBDuplicateEntry: raise exception.TokenInUse() @base.NovaObjectRegistry.register class ConsoleAuth(base.NovaObject): # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'token': fields.StringField(nullable=False), 'connection': fields.ObjectField(ConsoleConnection), } @staticmethod def create(context, ttl, instance_uuid, access_url_base, console_type, host, port, internal_access_path=None): """Create a console authorization. This will generate a token for the authorization and return a ConsoleAuth object. """ token = str(uuid.uuid4()) connection = ConsoleConnection( context=context, instance_uuid=instance_uuid, access_url_base=access_url_base, console_type=console_type, host=host, port=port, internal_access_path=internal_access_path, token_hash=utils.get_sha256_str(token), expires=timeutils.utcnow_ts() + ttl) connection.create() return ConsoleAuth(token=token, connection=connection) @staticmethod def validate(context, token, instance_uuid): """Validate a token and instance_uuid. :param context: the context :param token: authorized token :param instance_uuid: authorized instance uuid :returns: a console authorization if valid or None If the token and instance_uuid correspond to a console authorization the authorization (a ConsoleAuth object) will be returned. """ connection = ConsoleConnection.get(context, utils.get_sha256_str(token), instance_uuid) return ConsoleAuth(token=token, connection=connection) @base.remotable_classmethod def clean_all_for_instance(cls, context, instance_uuid): """Remove all console authorizations for the instance. :param context: the context :param instance_uuid: the instance to be cleaned All authorizations related to the specified instance will be removed from the database. """ db.console_auth_token_destroy_all_by_instance(context, instance_uuid) @base.remotable_classmethod def clean_expired_for_host(cls, context, host): """Remove all expired console authorizations for the host. :param context: the context :param host: the host name All expired authorizations related to the specified host will be removed. Tokens that have not expired will remain. """ db.console_auth_token_destroy_expired_by_host(context, host)

[docs] Clarify node requirements

Clarify text around the reference architecture node
requirements. Also fix some other minor issues.

Change-Id: Ic5544f60c765aef6b1ca02cfe417e057510a0c7b

added_lines: to deploy OpenStack with Open Virtual Network (OVN) integration for the Networking service in production with sufficient expectations of scale and performance. For evaluation purposes, you can deploy this environment using the :ref:`Installation Guide <installation>` orThe reference architecture includes a minimum of four nodes... note:: For functional evaluation only, you can combine the controller and database nodes. .. note:: By default, you must run these commands from the node containing the OVN databases.
deleted_lines: for a basic evaluation of OpenStack with Open Virtual Network (OVN) integration for the Networking service. You can deploy this environment manually using the :ref:`Installation Guide <installation>` or usingThe minimum environment includes four nodes.

subject: Remove IP availability range recalculation logic

commit_message:
Remove IP availability range recalculation logic

This patch removes unreachable code that rebuilds IP address
availability data and persists in the database. This is
ultimately derived data that is now computed in memory and never
persisted. The code being removed is dead code and does not
include the contract migration for removal of the
IPAvailabilityRange models.

Change-Id: I96cb67396b8e0ebbe7f98353fad1607405944e44
Partial-Bug: #1543094
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/38/303638/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def _rebuild_availability_ranges(self, session): """Rebuild availability ranges. This method should be called only when the availability ranges are exhausted or when the subnet's allocation pools are updated, which may trigger a deletion of the availability ranges. For this operation to complete successfully, this method uses a locking query to ensure that no IP is allocated while the regeneration of availability ranges is in progress. :param session: database session """ # List all currently allocated addresses, and prevent further # allocations with a write-intent lock. # NOTE: because of this driver's logic the write intent lock is # probably unnecessary as this routine is called when the availability # ranges for a subnet are exhausted and no further address can be # allocated. # TODO(salv-orlando): devise, if possible, a more efficient solution # for building the IPSet to ensure decent performances even with very # large subnets. allocations = netaddr.IPSet( [netaddr.IPAddress(allocation['ip_address']) for allocation in self.subnet_manager.list_allocations( session)]) # MEH MEH # There should be no need to set a write intent lock on the allocation # pool table. Indeed it is not important for the correctness of this # operation if the allocation pools are updated by another operation, # which will result in the generation of new availability ranges. # NOTE: it might be argued that an allocation pool update should in # theory preempt rebuilding the availability range. This is an option # to consider for future developments. LOG.debug("Rebuilding availability ranges for subnet %s", self.subnet_manager.neutron_id) for pool in self.subnet_manager.list_pools(session): # Create a set of all addresses in the pool poolset = netaddr.IPSet(netaddr.IPRange(pool['first_ip'], pool['last_ip'])) # Use set difference to find free addresses in the pool available = poolset - allocations # Write the ranges to the db for ip_range in available.iter_ipranges(): av_range = self.subnet_manager.create_range( session, pool['id'], netaddr.IPAddress(ip_range.first).format(), netaddr.IPAddress(ip_range.last).format()) session.add(av_range)

commit_message:
faq: Update HA to reflect ovsdb replication.

Update the HA section of the FAQ to reflect that ovsdb-server now
supports active/passive HA using replication.

Change-Id: I07a0fe4f64c1541e459ca820d605b80c91cc9c61
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/01/339201/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OVN also makes use of ovsdb-server for the OVN northbound and southbound databases. ovsdb-server supports active/passive HA using replication. For more information, see: https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/master/Documentation/OVSDB-replication.md
deleted_lines: OVN's northbound and sounthbound databases both reside in an instance of ovsdb-server. OVN started out using this database because it already came with OVS and is used everywhere OVS is used. If we aren't able to evolve ovsdb-server to suit our needs, OVN will switch to something else. Someone is looking at making ovsdb-server distributed for both scale and HA reasons. In the meantime, you can run this instance of ovsdb-server in an active/passive HA mode. This requires having the database reside on shared storage. If you don't want to use shared storage, Neutron is capable of rebuilding the OVN database after a failure. This process can be completed without any impact to the data path, but new resources created via Neutron will not take effect until the recovery process is complete. The recovery procedure would be roughly: 1. Detect that the node running the OVN northbound database has failed. 2. Enable the OVN northbound database on a new host, but prevent ovn-controller processes on compute nodes from connecting to the OVN southbound database while recovery is in progress. This can be done with either system firewall rules, or by removing the configuration of ovsdb-server that tells it to listen for connections on an address that ovn-controller instances are able to reach (See ovs-vsctl get-manager/set-manager/del-manager commands). 3. Restart ovn-northd pointed at the new database location(s) for the OVN northbound and southbound databases. 4. Run ``neutron-ovn-db-sync-util`` with ``--ovn-neutron_sync_mode=repair`` and with your neutron server configuration files (for example, ``--config-file /etc/neutron/neutron.conf`` and ``--config-file /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini``). When this command completes, the OVN databases will have been restored and ovsdb-server can be configured to allow connections from ovn-controller on compute hosts (See ovs-vsctl get-manager/set-manager/del-manager commands).

commit_message:
[PoC] Add Ansible v1.9.x compatibility

As we've hit a performance bug with Ansible 2.x [0], adding v1.9.x
compatibility seems benefitial.

- modify `ansible-playbook` invocation options to be v1.9.x compatible
- add top-level action playbooks for Ansible v1
  - set driver_info/<action>_playbook=<action>-v1.yaml to use Ansible v1
- todo: add v1 logging callback

[0] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/14219

Change-Id: I38e095bb3f4292219f984228d52953574d748fff
Related-Bug: #1526308

commit_message:
[PoC] Add callback for logging into Ironic log

With default config placement and actual logging into file/syslog will
interleave Ansible events into Ironic Conductor log, using the same
logging options as provided in ironic.conf.

For other cases (like DevStack, which by default logs simply to stderr)
path to ironic.conf and a file to log into can be set in provided ini
file for the Ansible callback

Change-Id: I2acde183004d76bd0a2d4653c11cd7de4d6cc69b
Related-Bug: #1526308
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/10/318610/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python import ConfigParser import os from ansible.plugins import callback from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from ironic.common import i18n from ironic import version basename = os.path.splitext(__file__)[0] config = ConfigParser.ConfigParser() ironic_config = None ironic_log_file = None try: config.readfp(open(os.path.join(basename, ".ini"))) if config.has_option('ironic', 'ironic_config'): ironic_config = config.get('ironic', 'ironic_config') if config.has_option('ironic', 'ironic_log_file'): ironic_log_file = config.get('ironic', 'ironic_log_file') except Exception: pass CONF = cfg.CONF DOMAIN = 'ironic' LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__, project=DOMAIN, version=version.version_info.release_string()) logging.register_options(CONF) conf_kwargs = dict(args=[], project=DOMAIN, version=version.version_info.release_string()) if ironic_config: conf_kwargs['default_config_files'] = [ironic_config] CONF(**conf_kwargs) if ironic_log_file: CONF.set_override("log_file", ironic_log_file) CONF.set_override("use_stderr", False) logging.setup(CONF, DOMAIN) class CallbackModule(callback.CallbackBase): CALLBACK_VERSION = 2.0 CALLBACK_TYPE = 'notification' CALLBACK_NAME = 'ironic_log' CALLBACK_NEEDS_WHITELIST = True def __init__(self, display=None): self.node = None def runner_msg_dict(self, result): self.node = result._host.get_name() name = result._task.get_name() res = self._dump_results(result._result, keep_invocation=True) return dict(node=self.node, name=name, res=res) def v2_playbook_on_task_start(self, task, is_conditional): # NOTE(pas-ha) I do not know (yet) how to obtain a ref to host # until first task is processed node = self.node or "Unknown" LOG.info(i18n._LI("Processing task %(task)s on node %(node)s."), dict(task=task.name, node=node)) def v2_runner_on_failed(self, result, ignore_errors=False): msg = "Ansible task %(name)s failed on node %(node)s: %(res)s" msg_dict = self.runner_msg_dict(result) if ignore_errors: LOG.warning(i18n._LW(msg), msg_dict) else: LOG.error(i18n._LE(msg), msg_dict) def v2_runner_on_ok(self, result): msg = "Ansible task %(name)s complete on node %(node)s: %(res)s" msg_dict = self.runner_msg_dict(result) LOG.info(i18n._LI(msg), msg_dict) def v2_runner_on_unreachable(self, result): msg = ("Node %(node)s was unreachable for Ansible task %(name)s: " "%(res)s") msg_dict = self.runner_msg_dict(result) LOG.error(i18n._LE(msg), msg_dict) def v2_runner_on_async_poll(self, result): msg = ("Polled ansible task %(name)s for complete on node %(node)s: " "%(res)s") msg_dict = self.runner_msg_dict(result) LOG.debug(msg, msg_dict) def v2_runner_on_async_ok(self, result): msg = ("Async Ansible task %(name)s complete on node %(node)s: " "%(res)s") msg_dict = self.runner_msg_dict(result) LOG.info(i18n._LI(msg), msg_dict) def v2_runner_on_async_failed(self, result): msg = "Async Ansible task %(name)s failed on node %(node)s: %(res)s" msg_dict = self.runner_msg_dict(result) LOG.error(i18n._LE(msg), msg_dict) def v2_runner_on_skipped(self, result): msg = "Ansible task %(name)s skipped on node %(node)s: %(res)s" msg_dict = self.runner_msg_dict(result) LOG.debug(i18n._LI(msg), msg_dict)

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/python # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- import hashlib import requests # code from IPA and Lucas patch DEFAULT_CHUNK_SIZE = 1024 * 1024 # 1MB class StreamingDownloader(object): def __init__(self, url, chunksize, hash_algo=None): # NOTE(pas-ha) sha1 is quaranteed to be available in Py>=2.5 hash_algo = hash_algo or 'sha1' self.hasher = hashlib.new(hash_algo) self.chunksize = chunksize resp = requests.get(url, stream=True) if resp.status_code != 200: raise Exception('Invalid response code: %s' % resp.status_code) self._request = resp def __iter__(self): for chunk in self._request.iter_content(chunk_size=self.chunksize): self.hasher.update(chunk) yield chunk def checksum(self): return self.hasher.hexdigest() def stream_to_dest(url, dest, chunksize, hash_algo): downloader = StreamingDownloader(url, chunksize, hash_algo) with open(dest, 'wb+') as f: for chunk in downloader: f.write(chunk) return downloader.checksum() def main(): module = AnsibleModule( argument_spec=dict( url=dict(required=True, type='str'), dest=dict(required=True, type='str'), checksum=dict(required=False, default=''), chunksize=dict(required=False, type='int', default=DEFAULT_CHUNK_SIZE) )) url = module.params['url'] dest = module.params['dest'] checksum = module.params['checksum'] chunksize = module.params['chunksize'] # NOTE(pas-ha) checksum parsing piece is adapted from get_url module if checksum == '': hash_algo, checksum = None, None try: hash_algo, checksum = checksum.rsplit(':', 1) # Remove any non-alphanumeric characters, including the infamous # Unicode zero-width space checksum = re.sub(r'\W+', '', checksum).lower() # Ensure the checksum portion is a hexdigest int(checksum, 16) except ValueError: module.fail_json(msg='The checksum parameter has to be in format ' '"<algorithm>:<checksum>"') if hash_algo not in hashlib.algorithms_available: module.fail_json(msg="%s checksums are not supported" % hash_algo) try: actual_checksum = stream_to_dest( url, dest, chunksize, hash_algo) except Exception as e: module.fail_json(msg=str(e)) else: if hash_algo and actual_checksum != checksum: module.fail_json(msg='Invalid dest checksum') else: module.exit_json(changed=True) from ansible.module_utils.basic import * # noqa main()

subject: [WIP] [POC] Ansible deploy driver alt impl
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-25 19:23:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/346ebf20ea3ae98fc20d414761285eed63d853ce', 'message': '[WIP] [POC] Ansible deploy driver alt impl

This is an alternative implementation for Ansible deploy driver
proof of concept.

All non-Python files are moved to `/etc/ironic/ansible_deploy/`
Each action is described by single playbook with roles, which is run whole.
Control of deployment types and cleaning steps is through tags and
auxiliary steps file for cleaning.
The playbooks for actions can be set per-node, as is cleaning steps
file.

Supports whole images and partition images with local boot:
- compressed images are downloaded to RAM and converted to disk device;
- raw images are streamed to disk directly from HTTP;
- config drive partition is currently supported for partition images only.

Cleaning is supported, only one clean step for disks shredding in PoC.

Requires Ansible >= 2.0.1
Neutron is mandatory.

Deploy ramdisk requirements: Python, sshd and used utilities.

Experimental DIB element:
https://github.com/pshchelo/stackdev/tree/master/dib_elements/ironic-ansible

Experimental TinyCore-based ramdisk
https://github.com/pshchelo/stackdev/tree/master/irsible

Tested on DevStack with VM.
128 MB RAM is found enough for a VM to deploy a standard qcow2 Cirros image
(download to RAM + convert to disk device) when using TinyCore-based
deploy ramdisk.

TODO:
- make scripts in "files" folders proper Ansible modules
- add callback hoooks for better logging during long single playbook run
- document variables available to playbooks

Related-bug: #1526308
Change-Id: I841e83b897c8e17fda0efcd1615c08a4aa296a65

commit_message:
[WIP] [POC] Ansible deploy driver alt impl

This is an alternative implementation for Ansible deploy driver
proof of concept.

Each action is described by single playbook with roles, which is run whole.
Control of deployment types and cleaning steps is through tags and
auxiliary steps file for cleaning.
The playbooks for actions can be set per-node, as is cleaning steps
file.

Supports whole images and partition images with local boot:
- compressed images are downloaded to RAM and converted to disk device;
- raw images are streamed to disk directly from HTTP;
- config drive partition is currently supported for partition images only.

Cleaning is supported, only one clean step for disks shredding in PoC.

Requires Ansible >= 2.0.1
Neutron is mandatory.

Deploy ramdisk requirements: Python, sshd and used utilities.

Experimental DIB element:
https://github.com/pshchelo/stackdev/tree/master/dib_elements/ironic-ansible

Experimental TinyCore-based ramdisk
https://github.com/pshchelo/irsible

Tested on DevStack with VM.
128 MB RAM is found enough for a VM to deploy a standard qcow2 Cirros image
(download to RAM + convert to disk device) when using TinyCore-based
deploy ramdisk.

TODO:
- make scripts in "files" folders proper Ansible modules
- add callback hoooks for better logging during long single playbook run
- document variables available to playbooks

Change-Id: I841e83b897c8e17fda0efcd1615c08a4aa296a65
Related-Bug: #1526308
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/42/310042/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: get disk device name shell: lsblk -rido NAME | head -n 2 | tail -n 1 register: device_name - block: - name: download configdrive data get_url: url: "{{ configdrive }}" dest: /tmp/{{ node_uuid }}.cndrive async: 600 poll: 15 when: "{{ configdrive != 'file' }}" - block: - name: get configdrive dir command: dirname {{ inventory_file }} connection: local register: config_dir - name: copy configdrive file to node copy: src: "{{ config_dir.stdout }}/{{ node_uuid }}.cndrive" dest: /tmp/{{ node_uuid }}.cndrive owner: root group: root mode: 700 - name: remove configdrive from conductor command: rm -f {{ config_dir.stdout }}/{{ node_uuid }}.cndrive connection: local when: "{{ configdrive == 'file' }}" - name: calculate configdrive size command: stat -c "%s" /tmp/{{ node_uuid }}.cndrive register: configdrive_size when: configdrive is defined - name: erase partition table command: dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/{{ device_name.stdout}} bs=512 count=36 when: "{{ preserve_ephemeral|default('no') != 'yes'}}" - name: get parted args command: parted_args.py /dev/{{ device_name.stdout}} {{ root_mb }} {{ swap_mb|default('0') }} {{ ephemeral_mb|default('0') }} {{ configdrive_size.stdout|default('0') }} {{ inventory_file }} register: parted_args_script connection: local sudo: false - name: run parted command: parted {{ parted_args_script.stdout }} when: "{{ preserve_ephemeral|default('no') != 'yes'}}" - name: format ephemeral partition command: mkfs -t {{ ephemeral_format }} -L ephemeral0 {{ ephemeral_part }} when: "{{ ephemeral_mb is defined and preserve_ephemeral == 'no' }}" - name: make swap command: mkswap -L swap1 {{ swap_part }} when: swap_mb is defined - name: write configdrive command: dd if=/tmp/{{ node_uuid }}.cndrive of={{ configdrive_part }} when: configdrive is defined

commit_message:
Delete unused discovery_url for swarm

The swarmnode of Swarm bay don't need discovery_url, so let's
delete it from heat templates.

Change-Id: I48f775e795e1985ada9da7d7660f159df13da7ac

commit_message:
Warn on legacy auth options on conductor start

Pre-load config during conductor start and assert that at least 'auth_type'
option in relevant services config sections is provided.
Log a warning if it is missing as this certainly indicates that
deprecated way of loading service user credentials from
[keystone_authtoken] section is going to be performed.

Change-Id: I3156537c296d870c1a4737ea35b71835945f5fa5
Related-Bug: #1422632

All documentation points that this variable is stored in
the database in seconds, while HA proxy expects this value
to be in milliseconds. This leads to a disparity in
expectations. Better solution would be to modify the docs
to tell people to use milliseconds.

Change-Id: Id8224e28826de6a9da2c378d97ad68779df2a99c
'}]
commit_message:
Modify template to write variable in seconds.

All documentation points that this variable is stored in
the database in seconds, while HA proxy expects this value
to be in milliseconds. This leads to a disparity in
expectations. Better solution would be to modify the docs
to tell people to use milliseconds.

Change-Id: Id8224e28826de6a9da2c378d97ad68779df2a99c

commit_message:
Reduce error messages from http_check

Only log the same error message once so it won't keep cluttering
the log file.

Add error message into value_meta

Change-Id: I3a7d53fd1d90abe0a8987e18743886db2aac7704

commit_message:
Fix magnum default service type

Magnum default service type changed from "container" to
"container-infra". It is recommended to update the service
type at Keystone service catalog accordingly.

Change-Id: I2ed1e6a5f4e6729846749cecef5d32e76c0ab149

Report VM metrics for both tenant and operator

Making sure to report VM metrics for the tenant that owns the VM and the
operator.

commit_message:
Masks hashed password in VIM CRUD responses

Implement hashed password masking for VIM CRUD APIs on server-side
rather than doing it on client-side.

Change-Id: Ice5c51b6a66cd27f21c144d3a672cf790e4cec41
Closes-Bug: #1594495

deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(vim_auth_password, res['auth_cred']['password'])

commit_message:
Add subresources support for PECAN

Implements adding a subresource (of extensions) to its parents
A resource and a subresource has a parent-child relationship, for example:
A qos resource has a subresource of bandwith_limit_rules. This patch will
allow urls like : /qos/policies/{policy_id}/bandwidth_limit_rules to work.

Change-Id: I43ce22ff0ab2ddcb2a1cc8965f423761f41d08c9

commit_message:
add node_deployment_info table

Size of deployment_info field in tasks table grows as n**2
(depending on number of nodes). If we have 200 nodes, the
size of the structure is about 20Mb. In case of 600 nodes it
would be theoretically about 720Mb, in practice it doesn't fit
into 1Gb.

Good solution is to put common part to separate place. But it's
not so fast. Also it will not help if all nodes will be going to
be deployed with customized deployment info.

Change-Id: Id3154ab423b0863d9cc4952335293bf5fc30df38
Partial-Bug: #1596987

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: I5b5bf304746010a518f9743661079ce061335eb4
(cherry picked from commit 5be9099016b16b5ccd9db1dfb65893b17d71ea26)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_container_create refs/changes/50/339650/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: minversion = 2.0install_command = pip install -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt} {opts} {packages} deps = -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = /usr/bin/find . -type f -name "*.pyc" -delete http_proxy HTTP_PROXY https_proxy HTTPS_PROXY no_proxy NO_PROXY bash -c "rm -rf doc/build"[testenv:releasenotes] # NOTE(sdague): this target does not use constraints because # upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} commands = sphinx-build -a -E -W -d releasenotes/build/doctrees -b html releasenotes/source releasenotes/build/html # NOTE(jaegerandi): this target does not use constraints because # upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} commands = {posargs}[testenv:ansible] deps = {[testenv]deps} ansible==1.9.4 ansible-lint>=2.7.0,<3.0.0 setenv = {[testenv]setenv} ANSIBLE_HOST_KEY_CHECKING = False ANSIBLE_SSH_CONTROL_PATH = /tmp/%%h-%%r # TODO (odyssey4me) These are only here as they are non-standard folder # names for Ansible 1.9.x. We are using the standard folder names for # Ansible v2.x. We can remove this when we move to Ansible 2.x. ANSIBLE_ACTION_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/action ANSIBLE_CALLBACK_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback ANSIBLE_FILTER_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/filter ANSIBLE_LOOKUP_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/lookup # This is required as the default is the current path or a path specified # in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_LIBRARY = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/library # This is required as the default is '/etc/ansible/roles' or a path # specified in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_ROLES_PATH = {homedir}/.ansible/roles:{toxinidir}/.. rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/plugins # This plugin makes the ansible-playbook output easier to read wget -O {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback/human_log.py \ https://gist.githubusercontent.com/cliffano/9868180/raw/f360f306b3c6d689734a6aa8773a00edf16a0054/human_log.py rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/roles [testenv:ansible-syntax] deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv} commands = {[testenv:ansible]commands}deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} ansible-lint {toxinidir}# NOTE(odyssey4me): this target does not use constraints because # it doesn't work in OpenStack-CI yet. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages} deps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv} {[testenv:ansible]commands} -e "install_test_packages=True" \ {toxinidir}/tests/test.yml -vvvvdeps = {[testenv:ansible]deps} setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv}

We are using the standard folder names for # Ansible v2.x. We can remove this when we move to Ansible 2.x. ANSIBLE_ACTION_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/action ANSIBLE_CALLBACK_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback ANSIBLE_FILTER_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/filter ANSIBLE_LOOKUP_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/lookup # This is required as the default is the current path or a path specified # in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_LIBRARY = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/library # This is required as the default is '/etc/ansible/roles' or a path # specified in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_ROLES_PATH = {homedir}/.ansible/roles:{toxinidir}/..deps = -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = {posargs}[testenv:ansible-syntax] rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible --ignore-errors \ ansible-lint {toxinidir}/tests/test.yml rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins \ {homedir}/.ansible/plugins # This plugin makes the ansible-playbook output easier to read wget -O {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback/human_log.py \ https://gist.githubusercontent.com/cliffano/9868180/raw/f360f306b3c6d689734a6aa8773a00edf16a0054/human_log.py ansible-galaxy install \ --role-file={toxinidir}/tests/ansible-role-requirements.yml \ --ignore-errors \ --force {toxinidir}/tests/test.yml [testenv:releasenotes] commands = sphinx-build -a -E -d releasenotes/build/doctrees -b html releasenotes/source releasenotes/build/html

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

(cherry picked from commit 18c0e962440f33301be59a8d1d50ebdee92daeb4)

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: Icb5d505b81f0d989ced653b9fc82e24c363dfea1
(cherry picked from commit 8068d1498933a4a37350ecaa6e14c2970ea050ac)

commit_message:
Fix argument order for assertEqual to (expected, observed)

assertEqual expects that the arguments provided to it should be
(expected, observed). If a particluar order is kept as a convention,
then it helps to provide a cleaner message to the developer if Unit
Tests fail. The following patch fixes this issue.

TrivialFix
Closes-Bug: #1259292

Change-Id: I608b07f857d9fa2d401cab35fff6bdf2defa6d55

commit_message:
Add destroyed container context manager

Required for running destroy docker contaier before code block and
startup it after block

Usage:

    from octane.util import docker

    with docker.destoyed_container("container_name"):
       ...

Change-Id: Iab57665d2b345bc19f04fad4c0cd4a4e461edd89

subject: Remove sleeps if testenv create/destroy fails
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-06 16:42:44.000000000', 'files': ['scripts/te-broker/create-env', 'scripts/te-broker/destroy-env'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/commit/8423c808a826695e27892872ed92030a7851c763', 'message': 'Remove sleeps if testenv create/destroy fails

This achieves nothing but make manual intervention on errors
necessary, this may be needed for some cases. But for others
it will be perfectly fine to allow the worker to continue handling
new envs.

Change-Id: Icc75a540157d5854d65317e239f5a75fcedcd32f
'}]
commit_message:
Remove sleeps if testenv create/destroy fails

This achieves nothing but make manual intervention on errors
necessary, this may be needed for some cases. But for others
it will be perfectly fine to allow the worker to continue handling
new envs.

Change-Id: Icc75a540157d5854d65317e239f5a75fcedcd32f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/94/338394/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use UCA for non-OVS neutron

This commit refactors tasks to allow the use of UCA for Linux Bridge.
It also changes default behavior: now every neutron install will
make use of Ubuntu Cloud Archive, unless mentionned.

Closes-Bug: 1497272
Closes-Bug: 1433172

Change-Id: I4373f544eb178720f33795a71adae925a8b8cb03
Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe.evrard@rackspace.co.uk>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron refs/changes/29/338129/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: neutron_use_uca: True

identic for both puppet and mcollective

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-08 08:44:11.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/metadata-proxy-cleanup-eed6ff482035dc83.yaml', 'handlers/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron/commit/ef5401ac3aeff6cc539e48d5c342640c0a7bd5d2', 'message': 'Cleanup metadata-proxy when old versions are present

commit_message:
Cleanup metadata-proxy when old versions are present

The metadata proxy service will now be cleaned up when this role is
executed if an old version of the metadata-proxy is still running.
Once the old versions of the metadata-proxy have been cleaned up
the metadata agent will respawn the correct process within 60 seconds.

This change is required to ensure upgrades are always executing the
correct code from a given release.

Change-Id: I3a0b5c5b75742f06a94e5334c749b88e54f7f43c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 86fc72bd69b8c5dc4ba35919e4302b04d95cea1f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron refs/changes/06/339406/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: notify: - Run ns-metadata-proxy process cleanup # NOTE(cloudnull): # When installing or upgrading it is possible that an old metadata proxy process will not # be restarted by the metadata agent when a version changes. To fix it the ns-metadata # proxy pids are killed if they're not running the current tag. Once the old processeses # are removed the metadata agent will respawn the missing process within 60 seconds using # the correct code. - name: Run ns-metadata-proxy process cleanup shell: | for ns_pid in $(pgrep neutron-ns-meta); do (echo $(readlink -f "/proc/$ns_pid/exe") | grep -qv "{{ neutron_venv_tag }}") && \ (echo "old metadata proxy pid found running clean up on $ns_pid"; kill -9 "$ns_pid") done when: neutron_services['neutron-metadata-agent'].service_en | bool

subject: Update tox configuration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-08 12:30:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cinder/commit/c4b68b9bfffbbeb5f6a2f3a6ba9d5ea5831e127b', 'message': "Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: Ice4884ebe0873fb433e0e93d4b1d7286dae36755
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-08 13:48:33.000000000', 'files': ['tests/ansible-role-requirements.yml', 'test-requirements.txt', 'tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cinder/commit/95a0f721e8424afe8b66035b6d5785d2b9712a5a', 'message': "Update tox configuration

some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use

- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test

- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed

- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into

- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: I7b68b4ccaf655e14a56804e3a004bb5abd4ec455

  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

commit_message:
Update tox configuration

In order to prepare for implementing requirements management by the
OpenStack requirements management process, and to improve the
reliability and effectiveness of test execution, this patch implements
some changes to the tox configuration:

- The minimum tox version is increased in order to be able to use
  constraints for the python packages.
- The OpenStack upper-constraints are used when preparing the test
  venv for the linters checks.
- Any proxy environment variables set on the test host are passed
  into the venv to enable testing from behind a proxy.
- The environment variables used by Ansible tests are moved into
  a new venv called 'ansible' and this environment is inherited
  by all Ansible-related tests.
- The docs test will clean-up an existing build directory before
  executing the docs build.
- The releasenotes build cannot use upper-constraints at this point,
  so it doesn't.
- The Ansible role download will no longer ignore errors so that any
  problems discovered will result in a failed test.
- The human readable logging callback plugin is implemented for
  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: Ic8b35f61bfcc8af3b37c895e47dc6fbad063d4b4

  functional testing.
- The ansible test requirements are moved into tox.ini to ensure
  compliance for requirements.txt/test-requirements.txt for the
  global-requirements management contract.
- The ~/.ansible directory as a whole is not deleted. Instead only
  the plugins and roles folders are deleted to ensure that zuul's
  Ansible artifacts are left in-place.
- The ansible-lint version is updated to support execution against a
  folder, and the test now executes against the entire role to ensure
  that it captures all applicable files for lint testing.

This is a combined port of the following:
- https://review.openstack.org/323507
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/332443
- https://review.openstack.org/338193
- https://review.openstack.org/339493

Change-Id: I46f916bfe0078a43ec6537e4e3e71be44acd4891
